title: Stepper Motor Shaft Coupler NEMA23 6.5mm Bore

description.text:
This part slips on to the shaft of a NEMA23 Stepper Motor with a 6.5mm shaft. There are four 6.5mm holes at the 12-3-6-9 o'clock positions for bolting something on. Set screw holes sized for 8-32 are at the 1:30 and 7:30 positions.
To ensure a properly sized hole, they are printed undersized and need to be drilled out. I use this metric drill bit set from Amazon.

No

No

Resolution:

0.5mm Nozzle, 0.1mm Layer

25%

comments.text: very dangerous - laser cutters typically come with eye protection and and exhaust. using one with a traditional 3d printer (even an enclosed design) would not mitigate these factors and the risk to eyes and noxious fumes are real concerns. These concerns could be addressed fairly easily (goggles, diy exhaust, etc) but I'd imagine you'd have to add quite a bit of power to the extruder point to run an actual c02 laser that could cut stuff in a reasonable amount of time. That would be the deal breaker for me - at that point you've added laser windows, glasses, an exhaust system, and replaced your extruder so why not just build a dedicated device at that point and leave your 3d printer alone

title: Folding dressing stick with paper grabber attachment

description.text: This dressing stick is folding so that a person with limited mobility can bring it easily in a suitcase. I designed this for my mother in law, who has a dressing stick she likes to travel with. The problem with her current stick is that it sticks out of the bag when she travels. This makes it annoying to travel with. I also created a paper grabber so that someone who cannot bend easily can use the paper grabber attachment to pick up a paper that has been dropped onto the floor. This is a simple task but very hard for someone with rheumatoid arthritis. Update 1: I successfully printed most of the parts, and I have assembled the dressing stick! The sleeves that slide over the joints to keep the stick from folding are a little oversize. I will be measuring and adjusting the files accordingly. Watch for new uploads here with adjusted slides for the joints. Update 2: I adjusted the sleeve for better fit and uploaded that file. I also finished printing the folding dressing stick and added pictures of it. I need to still work a little more on the pins so they do not fall out so easily. Update 3: I uploaded a new pin file (v3) and removed the old pin files. I cleaned out the pin holes with a 15/64th drill bit and now the pins are tighter fit with the new pin files. The stick seems to be fully functional now! I will be giving it to my mother in law to see how she likes using it. Update 4: It works great! Here's a video of my mother in law using the folding dressing stick: https://youtu.be/0yo32NhIssE

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

75%

Notes: Most parts (except the handle) will have 100% infill because they are thin.

You may need to drill out the holes for the pins with a 15/64th drill bit before assembling. I printed this in Matter Hackers Pro PLA filament.
The paper grabber requires a rubber band for the latch to operate. The files included have assembly diagrams.

remixed_from.title: Light Switch Face Plate with Solidworks 2014 source

description.text:
Star Wars light switch plate that I made for my sons bedroom. I used glow in the dark ABS for the upper layers so when he shuts off the lights you can see the death star and tie fighter with background stars. I had to remove the right side of the stl in order to get it to fit my sons light switch because of the woodwork. We live in an old house and the woodwork around his door frame is almost 6 inches wide. I did not modify the model I have posted here, but if you look at the real pictures you will see that the right side is narrow compared to the model. If you need to make any changes to get it to fit,
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/h9785qTWZPh

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2 mil

Infill:

20%

Notes: I made this for my son's bedroom. I printed this at 2 mil with supports (the bottom is hollow to accommodate the light switch) and 20% infill and between the 28th and 29th layer I paused my printer and swapped out the black filament for glow in the dark then resumed printing. you may need to play with your slicer to figure out just where to pause it, but it will look pretty cool when it's done.
Note that on my printer not all of the stars in the background printed and most that did fell off while I was removing the supports. Don't be surprised if yours does the same. Enjoy!

description.text:
My mother is a stroke survivor who has very limited use of her right hand. When she got a new iPad, I realized that it can be very hard to take pictures with only one hand. She is a talented artist and expresses herself through her art. And I wanted her to be able to easily take pictures of her art. This double easel is very adjustable and works with smartphones and tablets of most sizes (I have tested iPad Mini, iPad 2, and a Galaxy S5). This works with standard (US size) dowels of 7/16" (you'll need a couple yards). You will also want some 4 x 1/2 wood screws to hold things into place. Note: After testing this out, I am considering designing it with thicker dowels for even more stability. Blog
Facebook
Twitter

No

No

Low

Infill:

Standard

Notes: This printed well on a Replicator 2 with the "Low" defaults.

I will add more info about assembly, but its pretty straightforward. You'll need dowels, screws, and a screwdriver. 
The "saw" files are for the teeth. There are left and right versions (with the screw hole on the bottom side.)
I used Rhino for Mac to design all of the geometry.

remixed_from.author: kapudon
remixed_from.title: Configurable OpenSCAD Square Tubing Connector Generator

title: Square tubing filament rack and roller

description.text:
Just what the world needs, another custom filament roller. This one can be configured as a filament spool rack, roller, or both, in an almost infinite number of permutations. This fully annotated OpenSCAD code will render connectors and roller bearing supports to build your custom filament rack and/or roller from aluminum square tubing. The variable dimensions are pre-configured for standard 1" x 0.065" wall tubing, but should be easily customizable for other sizes (not extensively tested). In addition to the connectors, which are the same as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790145 (which was in turn remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14061), you can use this code to create stl files for roller bearing supports that are either integrated into corner connectors or that slide along tubing sections. The sliders accommodate variable spool thicknesses, so you will want at least one per rail, per spool. There is also an option for a sliding filament guide that fits between rollers and connects to a PTFE guide tube. All these parts can be seen in the photos of my rack, which sits behind my dual extrusion Flashforge Creator Pro. The roller bearing supports are sized for standard 608 skate bearings, and have integrated spacers so you can attach them securely with 5/16" bolts, and they will spin freely. These bearings are cheap (about $1 each) and easy to find. No need for high end performance bearings (unless your printer is really fast!). UPDATE 1/1/2016:
Version 2.1 has a couple of new options.
  • The integrated bearing spacer on the support tabs can now be selected to print on one side or both sides of the tab (or none). Two sides is nice, but prevents the tab from lying flat on the print bed, so you will need to reorient and may need support
  • The exit hole size and orientation on the sliding filament guide funnel can now be specified. Popular guide tube sizes of 4 or 6 mm both work. You will probably want to add a fraction for clearance (e.g., 6.1 for a 6mm tube). The variable "guidetype" specifies a straight through guide (downward exit angle) or a bent guide tube (horizontal exit angle).
    • I recently modified my filament rack, moving the rollers from the edges to the center, and raising the top level above my printer height. The last two photos show the new setup.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

50%+

Notes: You need OpenSCAD to render stl files for the pieces you want to print using this code. OpenSCAD is opensource software, and can be downloaded for your computer platform here: http://www.openscad.org/ Open the rendering code, and follow the embedded directions to customize for each part you want to render. I have only printed these in ABS. PETG should also work well. I wouldn't trust PLA. 0.2mm and 50% infill has worked well for me. I wouldn't use sparse infill on connectors. You will need support on any connector fingers which are parallel with your print bed. Be careful to position support under each and every finger vein or your connector may not fit right. PRINT A TEST FINGER AND SHELL FIRST! with the sizing test option. Different tubing, filaments, and setups may require dimensional tweaking for a good fit. Deburr your cut tubing thoroughly inside and out prior to test fitting.

Get some 1" aluminum tubing and cut to desired dimensions to build your rack.  A chop saw or metal bandsaw is nice for square ends, but a hacksaw can work fine if you are careful.  Carefully deburr cut ends inside and out with a file or sandpaper.
Be reasonable when it comes to loading.  You can easily shear off the connector fingers with sudden force or too much weight.  They are strong enough when static, but won't handle flexing.  Disassembly in particular is tricky without cracking or breaking off fingers, if you have a tight fit.  You may not be able to reuse connectors.

author: WouterVV

title: OnePlus Two Usb Dock (For One Plus Two)

description.text:
This is a simple OnePlus Two Usb Dock which utilizes the included usb-cable of the OPT. When you print this model yourself, don't forget to drop a photo of your make here! If you have any questions or suggestions, just write in the comments. :) Greets from Germany,
nexster.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Use high infill for at least the upper part.

I designed this dock because there were none avaible on Thingiverse or somewhere else.
I used Fusion360 to make the model.

There is a chance that this dock will work for other mobile phones. The OnePlus One will not fit, because it is 1mm wider than the OnePlus Two. Maybe I'll make a second version for the OnePlus One.
Please notice: This dock will not fit the OnePlus Two with a case! The dock is built around the dimensions of the OPT without a case.

Oct 31 2015 First Prototype Nov 1, 2015 Added more space on the side so OPT can slip in easily. Reduced space in the front so the OPT can not wiggle around. Changed the design so the front buttons and power button of the OPT can be reached easily. Nov 1, 2015 // 2 Design printed and it fits! So I call this finished :)

Print the two included parts. Route the cable from the back into the dock and bring it to the top through the hole. It's USB-C, so in the end it doesn't matter which way! Push the cable to the top until the plug sticks out (see pictures). Secure the cable with the second part you printed. It will rest into the printed notch in the front of the dock (you have put the cable in there earlier). It's pretty self explaining, I'm sure you're going to find out how to assemble the dock. :3 P.S: Maybe you will have to sand the part that holds the cable in place a bit. It is pretty tight without sanding. If you sand it a bit, you will be able to get your cable out again. ^^ If your device pulls the cable out of the dock when unplugging just fix the cable to the dock with some double sided tape. It's best to stick some double sided tape where the cable exits the dock on the back and then press the cable on to the tape. If you want, you can fix the plug directly with some double sided tape in the dock itself, or even glue it. This way it will stay in place. If you want, you can stick some bookbinding cloth or something similar on the inside, where the OPT slides. It looks better and the OPT won't get any scratches!

Laser cut cassette rack! Holds 16 of your favorite tapes!

Instructions:  
1) Find a laser cutter at your nearest hackerspace, makerspace or fab lab.  
2) Cut 1 set of sides and 3 sets of slats from 1/4" birch plywood.   
3) Assemble and glue.   
4) Let dry.  
5) (Optional) If it's not hung on a wall, cut some more plywood, backing board or cardboard to attach to the back. This keeps your cassettes from sliding out.
I designed this in Inkscape using a grid for the birch plywood width.

Lazy glasses are used to save your neck while you're whatching TV, reading a book or just playing with your tablet.
They "bend" the light so that you don't have to look at what you want to see. The splints are designed to fit very tight in the glasses so you might have to use a bit of force to get them in place, just be carefull not to brake them.

Dimensions and inspiration I looked around on Thingverse to see if i could find interesting things that needed improvements or was not yet created, and couldn't find any lazy glasses, therefore i decided to make it.
Usually lazy glasses have a prism to bend the light, but since a good prism often cost more than the buyable glasses i decided to use mirrors instead.
The problem with a mirror is that everything that gets reflected in it will become mirrored, inverted.
So for this to work it needs 2 mirrors for each eye which will mirror it twice and then everything should work just fine. You can print everything except of the 4 small mirrors that will be glued on the inside of the glasses.

description.text: I have been playing around with creating wrecked models for use in scifi wargaming, and I have a soft spot for 40K even though I don't play so much any more. I started with Garin's excellent dreadnought model and went to work creating a terrain piece from it. The backpack, meant to be printed separately, is Stewart Pope's alternative pack, just included here for convenience. The "complete" version is really just for show; I think it will be better to print as separate pieces.

The base and terrain are generated using a fractal terrain generator that I wrote and OpenSCAD, as are the barrel and the little cables sticking out of the broken arm. Everything was then pulled into Blender for editing.
Basically I reassembled the majority of Garin's model from the parts in Blender, combining with the other bits and pieces and merging into a single form for printing.
The "complete" version still has a bit of internal structure, and I didn't try to merge the pack into the body, as I didn't intend that to be printed.

title: PZ0420 FPV Camera Case w/ Guard

description.text:
Feeling generous and want to support my design work? Visit my Myminifactory page and leave a tip, It would be greatly appreciated.
https://www.myminifactory.com/users/EthanNewhouse I was tired of looking for a case that fit my specs exactly, so I designed one. Super simple design but very effective. This is designed for the PZ0420 camera at 38mm x 38mm. This Guard slips on to completely encases the camera and lens so the likely-hood of damaging the fragile lens is minimal at best. There are two back options, one for video only and one for all the different connections. Both backs have a relief for the capacitor that protrudes from the PCB. Glue together using epoxy for a clear finish. Print it in different colors for a more custom look. As always, I am open to feedback, so if you run into issues let me know. Happy printing, and happy flying!

title: Low Profile Tires/Rims for OpenR/C F1 car

description.text:
2017-04-21 added 2 rims & 1 tire for the wider rear 2017 wheel ‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾
PLEASE RESPECT THE LICENSE AND GIVE CREDIT TO THE DESIGNER!
‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾
Anyone interested in the work of Daniel Noreé has probably not missed the fact that he has released - OpenR/C Formula 1. The F1 car can be printed in PLA and is designed so that everybody will be able to print and build it without any hassle. Even a ball bearing kit is now available http://www.fasteddybearings.com/openrc-f1-sealed-bearing-kit/ for the car :- ) I created some rain tires for the original rims but I also designed these low profile rim/tires just for fun. The low profile tires feature a new snap-on design that will secure the tire using a triangular shape that´s interconnecting the parts. Also the tires are not sealed with this design, making them a bit softer since the air is not trapped inside (but I also included a solid version). This snap-on design is also available for tires/rims that can be used with the OpenR/C Touring Car or similar RC cars naturally. Download the Touring rims here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001223 and the tires here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001233 Enjoy! Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/
http://palmiga.com/ Follow me on Instagram and/or twitter:
http://instagram.com/rubber3dprinting
https://twitter.com/rubber3dprint For more info regarding release of the F1 car and also the other Open-RC project head over in this direction: http://danielnoree.com/
For OpenR/C Formula 1 print-files (after release) go here: https://pinshape.com/users/18846-danielnoree
For my designs check out http://www.thingiverse.com/Palmiga/designs & https://www.instagram.com/rubber3dprinting/ Due to the nature of 3D printing / material used etc... Keep in mind that you use my designs on your own risk and that I in no way is responsible for any damage och injuries.

I did give it a try but it won't fit.
The diff https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2361718 only works with the spoke layout of the original rims.

Your spokes have a different layout.

Spanish: (See below for english)
Necesitaba unas etiquetas pequeñas para unos cablecillos. Seguro que hay una solución mejor, pero en ese momento lo diseñé porque era más rápido que andar buscándolo. A mi me funcionan. Haz un puñado de ellos, son baratos, rápidos, útiles y fáciles de poner y quitar. Debería haberlos hecho hace tiempo, para mi se han convertido en una cosilla necesaria.
Hmm espero que tengas un rotulador mejor que el mio. El ABS ayuda a retener la tinta. En caso de que necesites ponerlos en cables mas gordos simplemente escálalos en XY.
Divirteté etiquetando! Actualización (3-NOV-2015): Incluido un .stl de un TAG con doble agujero para mantenerlo mejor fijado al cable si resulta necesario. También he añadido uno vertical y otro redondo más grande. Elije el que más te guste. English:
I was in the need of a small tag for small cables. For sure exist a better solution, but I just design it at that moment because it was quicker than searching for it. It works for me. Make a bunch of them, they are cheap, quick, handy and easy to plug/unplug. I should have done this time ago, it has become a "must have" thingie for me. Hmmm. I hope you've got a better sharpie than mine.... Also ABS helps retaining the ink.
In case you need to fit bigger diameter cables just XY scale it...
Happy tagging... Update (3-NOV-2015): Included a .stl for a double fit hole TAG to keep it firmly attached to the cable in case of convenience... Added also a vertical TAG and a bigger circular one. Choose your favourite.

description.text:

Centered on using the the same head-stock as in the wood lathe, the rest of the tools will be based around the same style. The bearing on the head-stock can be fitted to the lathe, as I found the shaft has a tendency to float back and forth, so this fixes that problem. The mandrel for the grinding wheel is a standard Dremel mandrel that I cut the 3mm end off and drilled it to suit my motor. Stay tuned for more pocket tools for modelling. PARTS LIST

SADDLE x 1
TOOL-REST 1
stand x 1
bearing to suit motor shaft OD is 10mm ( my motor had 1/8")
4mm cap screws x 1

motor to suit mine is from an old battery drill

author: freakshow29

description.text: It's not just their people that need a helping hand - assistance dogs also need help manipulating an environment not designed for them. This starter kit includes a light switch paddle, a doorknob puller, and also a unique set of scent coded training fobs that make it easier for dogs to distinguish between multiple targets in a cluttered environment. Each of the pairs of colored training fobs can be filled with different scents - e.g.: I've got oregano in both the green ones and garlic flakes in both the blue ones. Dogs are very good at distinguishing between scents, so when given the owner's copy of a fob to sniff (say, blue/garlic), they can easily find the matching target (blue/garlic) to work on.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Assembly For the scent fobs, print 2 each of the fob body and the fob cap in the same color. Print different pairs using different colors so that you (a human) can easily identify them. For the doorknob handle, both pieces are part of the same handle STL file. You will also need two 3/4" long 6-32 screws to secure the handle to the knob, and a length of 3/16" dia. rope for the dog to pull on. Attach the handle so that it is angled upward when the door is closed. For the light switch paddle, print one wall bracket, one switch nub, one lever and two links. The lever assembles to the wall bracket with two 6-32 x 3/8" screws. The links assemble to the switch nub and the lever with two more 6-32 x 3/8" screws. The two links are connected with an 18" length of 1/4" dia. dowel (cut longer or shorter depending on your dog's height). If the switch nub does not want to stay on the end of the switch, there is a hole for another 6-32 clamping screw. Slip the switch nub over the end of the light switch and then screw the wall bracket to the wall so that when the switch is up, the lower part of the paddle lever is pressed in. The lever should be at nose height.

Training Put matching smelly stuff in each pair of fobs. Try using things with distinct odor that aren't too much like food (don't use cheese or chicken). I've used spices, but you could also put in a cotton ball with a drop or two of some aromatic oil. The tops secure to the fobs with a bayonet-type screw. Collect one of each color fob together to form the owner's "command" set of fobs. Clip different color/odor fobs into the upper and lower parts of the switch lever and into the doorknob handle. You can also tie a fob to any article you might want fetched. I'm not an expert in dog training at all, but training will require separate steps of training different actions (such as pushing on a paddle, pulling a rope, or fetching a pouch) and of training matching-to-sample behavior - that is, how to select the thing that matches the smell of fob offered by the owner. I've only just started working with my own dog, but here is a video describing how to train matching-to-sample: http://stalecheerios.com/dog-training/match-to-sample-clicker-training/ I'll be posting more as I learn more myself.

title: Customizable Bolt Blank for Cutting in CAD

description.text: A parameterisable SCAD file for generating blank nuts and/or bolts based on the maximum standard tolerances outlined for metric hex bolts. I built this file to let me easily produce bolts with Hex heads for use in some of my other CAD designs. Essentially all variables can be adjusted to account for material tolerances. A few points that may be worth noting: Bolt Length by default is defined as double the diameter of the hex bolt unless you set it manually (by multiplier or manually in millimetres). Once changed in the Customizer - if you need a different/known length on the bolts etc. - you will have automatically overridden the multiplier setting and it will not be taken into account unless the manual setting is taken back to zero first. Tolerance is best set at about 0.5mm (+) above the standard sizing to account for shrinkage - I've found this gives a good friction fit with ABS but requires no post work. I used this setting when embedding parts mid-print and it worked very well.

I designed this dog food bowl to slow down my dog's eating. I added version 2 that prints faster. It may be a bit flimsier though. After printing the original version, I thought the pillars were a bit too big for one of my dogs muzzle to get in between them. I added version 3 which has braces for the side walls. It prints in almost exactly the same time as version 2 on my setup. Version 3 seems to be the best compromise of print speed and rigidity. V1, V2, V3 are all 135 mm in diameter. V4 is 180mm in diameter for larger breeds. It is also taller so it can handle more food.
The order of the models in the viewer is in ascending order. V1, V2, V3, V4. Choose which one best works for you.

My device is a spoon that can rotate 360 degrees so that the food inside will not be spilled. This helps people with Parkinson's disease and people with other disorders that cause them to have shaky hands, which leads to a difficulty in feeding themselves. The Gyrospoon helps alleviate that difficulty by using gyroscopic technology to keep the spoon part facing upward at all times.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

10%

Notes: I used ABS for the parts but you could probably use PLA instead. I think that it would work just as well. I also would've used ABS and the Makerbot HIPS dissolvable filament but with such a short time frame after I had come up with my idea, I was not able to get my hands on the D-Limonene that is needed to dissolve the filament in time. You could use any printer to print out the design, but I used a combination of the Makerbot Replicator 2 and 2x as that was the most convenient for me at school.

Prototype Picture The picture of the prototype that I have on this page is a little bit messed up. The inner part of the Gyrospoon was scaled down too much in the Makerbot software, so it doesn't fit as well as it did in the computer model. To fix this, I just added a short piece of paperclip to bridge the gap. Be cautious if using the Makerbot Desktop software to make sure that all of your pieces are scaled the same.

Design When I was designing my entry for this competition, I was thinking about things that help people with disorders, and I thought about spoons that use gyroscope technology. The only problem with them is that they need electricity and are made out of things other than 3D printed material. I thought that I could design a spoon that uses the same concept, but is able to be fully 3D printed. It took me a little while to first come up with a solid design that I felt could work, but after 3D printing a few pieces I realized that I had to make some changes with spacing and supports, as the first print had no supports or spacing so the handle and switch were one big piece instead of two pieces with supports separating them. After that, everything else was pretty fine except I changed the thickness of all of the pieces from one quarter of an inch to three quarters.

Files The Gyrospoon files come with the handle and switch together in an assembly. The switch has enough space inside the handle so that there are supports there and not solid plastic. The files also come with the outer ring of the whole thing, and the spoon piece itself. These pieces are all needed in order for the gyrospoon to function. There are some optional pieces that you can use to improve the function of the Gyrospoon even though it already functions very well. These pieces are the locks. They go on the outside of the outer ring and spoon posts (the little pins that go into the whole of the piece to the outside) The switch may also be optional. Even though it is a part of one of the necessary pieces, you only need it when you are trying to eat something that is semi-solid. You would not need the witch if you were trying to eat something like soup.
Video The video below is just a demonstration of how the Gyrospoon works.

title: Wacom Cintiq 12WX Wall Mount for Converter Unit

description.text:
I've been using a Wacom Cintiq 12WX for a while now, and the wires were starting to get hard to control. This is a wallmount for the converter box so it can sit behind a desk and keep the wires all nice and tucked away. It keeps the USB, power, and video cables underneath, and leaves access for the tablet cable on top. There are clips built in to keep it in place when removing the tablet cord, but the box can still be easily removed.   
This is designed to try to use as little material as possible, so it is designed thin and has a lot of holes. I printed mine without support, as I tried to design for it, but ran into some issues when it tried to print the wall mount circles, as it tried to do the outlines of the circles before the bridging. You might want to drill the holes out anyways to match the size of your screws/nails. I have included the Solidworks 2010 assembly of this (one part the Wacom Converter Unit, one part the wall mount) so you can change it as you see fit. If you don't have Solidworks and would like me to remove the holes so the bridging works better, just ask.  
Enjoy!

title: Metal Car - Kossel Metal Carriage for Vslot 2020

description.text:
I've now split this to 4 separate designs.
metalcar carriage for cnc - has a svg file - note the svg is in mm per point
metalcar carriage with stepper for cnc - has a svg file - note the svg is in mm per point
metalcar_prt for 3d printing - has a stl file
metalcar_stepper_prt for 3d printing - has a stl file Im in the process of building a full metal Kossel 3d Printer. I've already fabbed metal corners, and want to do carriage and effector in metal. This is my current work in progress for the carriage. Its designed for 3 wheels from openbuilds, and a ecentric spacer for tension.
The car usings a iron cup and a rare earth magnet. The cup is threaded from the rear for a m3 screw. The upwards retangular is designed for mounting of a magnet, or with tape a flag for optical, or to push a switch. https://github.com/glennswest/metalcar.git

OpenScad This is done in OpenScad, and then uses projection to make into 2d, and allows export of dxf and vector graphics. I intend to use cambam and cut it on cnc. Can also be laser cut. https://github.com/glennswest/metalcar.git

BOM and Assembly One Car consists of Qty Description URL
3 Delrin V Wheel Kit http://openbuildspartstore.com/delrin-v-wheel-kit/
1 Ecentric Spacer http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
2 Magnetic Can Coming Soon from NCC
2 Magnets Coming Soon from NCC
2 M3 Screws For Mounting mag cups
2 M3 Grub Screws For Mounting Magnets You need 3 sets of the above for a Kossel Printer

This is a substitute handle to the flexible bucket which has got its handles torn off.

author: glassy

description.text:
Made this Soundwave Tardis Transformer for an Instuctable contest, and thought I'd post it up here as well.
I originally only had Soundwave in mind when I was designing this. So all the small details are based around his robot design. But I was catching heck for making the Tardis into a Decepticon so I repainted him and added a second head option to make him Vector Prime. I still think Soundwave would make an awesome Tardis, but anyone making this has their option of which to build.
The files are for the Mark3 version, so the pictures and renders may look different than what you print.

Detailed build instructions and transforming process can be found on the Instructables page: http://www.instructables.com/id/Tardis-Transformer-Pick-your-flavor/
7/10/13 update:
All files synced with my own. So this is the current version posted here as of the 10th.
Added door details, changed the neck transformation back to the Mark1, completly redid the ankles and feet, and tweaked a few dimentions of the joints.
Printed this with a .35mm nozzle at .25mm hieght. Keep support on and I used a 6mm raft.
You'll need one of everything with two exceptions: 8 windows, and 2 outer back support.
Joint holes are 2.5mm. I used 1.78mm nylon filament, but you should be able to drill them out to 3mm if you need to. I'd like to switch the joint holes to 1.75mm filament but I don't have any on hand.
Everything is snap fit, but the tolerances are super tight so a bit of shaving may be required. If you take too much off, or if your joints are lose, hit it with a coat of lacquer paint until it's nice and tight.
Any problems printing, or any questions, feel free to ask!

description.text:
This toothbrush holder may not be as exciting or complicated an item as many of the items I have seen on Thingiverse, but I like it for what it showed about the usefulness of 3D printers in our family's everyday lives.
My mother-in-law emailed me, one day early this year, about the upcoming surgery on her hand. She was going to be without the use of her right hand for several weeks and was wondering if I could print some sort of thing that would hold her toothbrush so that she "could squirt toothpaste on the toothbrush without it falling over". She had been practicing and it "falls over all the time".
An hour later I had a holder for her to use.
From request to idea to prototype to usable item in an hour. An extremely simple item, but it made a big difference in her life. One more person sold on the usefulness of 3D printers.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

solid

Notes: Printed with Taulman 3D PCTPE. I printed a test one using ABS, and it worked fine, but the flex plastic gripped the toothbrush better.
We used a 3M Command Strip to stick the holder to the counter to keep it from slipping while inserting and removing the toothbrush.

author: Pistachio7950

title: Smooth X-axis for Prusa i3 with Leadscrews

description.text:
NOTE: X-MOTOR.STL and X-IDLER.STL are made for 22mm spacing UPDATE 15.5.2016
  • moved X-stepper mount point 5mm to left for 21mm version (X-MOTOR_21mm_WIDER.STL)
    • UPDATE 14.2.2016
  • made parts with 21mm spacing for Geeetech i3 pro c
    • UPDATE 29.12.2015
  • I had identified wrongly the idler bearings my printer came with. They're F693ZZ, not F623ZZ. With latter GT2 belt could not move freely. I have modified the clearance of the belt tensioners arm part so that both bearings should now work.
  • Updated belt tensioner arm part is added as own file for those that have printed the complete set before.

X-axis with fixed X-endstop and finger adjustable belt tensioner. Nothing new compared to already published (like ffleurey's thing:169636 and jkoljo's thing:372056). It's just this smooth looking design I like and wanted to share it. Note that there's no spesific Z-endstop trigger point as I prefer inductive proximity switch (mounted with the extruder). The distance between Z-axis's smooth rod and leadscrew is not same in all Prusa i3 versions. The kit I bought from Aliexpress.com is having 8mm acrylic frame and designed with 22mm distance but it seems that 17mm is more common. Also in Geeetech I3 X the distance is different, 27mm.
  • I have made necessary modifications and now there's X-motor and X-idler for 17mm, 21mm and 27mm distance too. Please inform me if the design has any faults.
  • stepper motor mounting point is moved 5mm to the left in X-MOTOR_27mm (Geeetech I3 X)
    • GT2 belt ends should stay in place without zip-ties. My printer is fixed in enclosed cabinet so belt removal is easier and doesn't require removal of X-carriage.

2 x F623ZZ (3x10x4) or F693ZZ (3x8x4) flanged bearing (idler) 4 x M3 20mm recessed head screw (stepper + idler) 1 x M3 nyloc nut (idler) 6 x M3 12mm hex socket screw (leadscrew nuts) 2 x M3 10-16mm hex socket screw (tensioner) 2 x M3 nut (tensioner) 1 x M4 20-30mm hex screw (tensioner) 1 x M4 nut (tensioner)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.25 mm layer height

Infill:

30% honeycomb

Notes: All parts have necessary built-in supports. X-idler's "comb"-supports are 0.5mm width. If slicing generates problems with these, try to change default extrusion width to ≤0.5mm.

Supports should be easily removable. X-endstop has tiny supports, that I carefully cut out with small blade. If you find there's not enough room for smooth rod, carefully ream the holes with 8mm drill bit. Design clearance is only 0.05mm. Note that X-axis's smooth rod may not be exactly coincident with X-idler's right end when assembled. It is essential that there's no bending of Z-axis's rods when X-axis moves along it. Take your time to achieve this before tensioning X-belt. Belt tensioner block has separate guidance piece that should be glued in right place. Make sure there's no binding between this piece and mating hole in X-idler's right end when assembled. Idler bearing holder should also move without binding. Design clearance is 0.25mm in all sides. Before adjusting belt tension, make sure there's small gap between tensioner block and X-idler's right end to prevent bending the Z-axis's smooth rods and leadscrew.

description.text:
Partially a conceptually symbolic piece, partially a decorative hairpiece, the Thornament is primarily an aesthetically concerned artifact. If you print one, it could definitely be worn, but be warned that wearing it will not be a particularly simple process, and it’s likely you’ll have to be a little careful so that the pins won’t snap.
While roses are classical objects, invoking romantic passion and all that jazz, people should also keep in mind that every rose has its thorns. Frankly, that’s part of its charm. Some things are all the more beautiful because of the fact that you could literally bleed from a dozen places just from a single touch.
By printing a Thornament, you can simply revel in its ornamental value. However, with the spines on the pins, you’ll also have a continuous reminder of what might lay under superficial beauty and retain a sense of concealed edges.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I haven't tested this without rafts and supports, so I suggest you use them. However, afterwards you'll probably have to spend upwards of ~3 hours on cutting the supports off of the chains. Think of the blood, sweat, and tears you’re providing as an additional aspect that will further add to your final enjoyment of the object. Then, all you have to do is attach the chains to the ornamental piece, by clipping the chain ends onto the opposing parts. A hot glue gun can help you permanently attach the separate pieces, if that's what you want.

description.text: Hi, my name is Brian Thornber. I am a 16 year old 11th grade student, interested in becoming a 3D Printing Engineer. I've made an object, to help me improve my skills, and to help other people with every day problems. Introducing the HandiHook. The HandiHook is a device, used to help people pick up various bags. Using the HandiHook, people will be able to pic up more bags, or it may simply help people who have trouble picking up bags. This is a very simple design, and is easy to print. It is scaled up to size, so no messing around with sizes needed. The standard print time for this is around an hour. The HandiHook V3 has stronger hooks than the first and second version, and requires much less plastic than the first one. I got the remix file (version 2) from a fellow user, cmdrironman, who has helped me with updating and evolving the HandiHook. I urge you to check out his remix (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1079544). Version 3 however, has much stronger hooks, and a handle design that should print better than Version 2. I however am out of plastic and cannot print one out for myself. I've included a sketch of how the HandiHook should be used. If you are a fellow user and wish to remix this, please shoot me a message, and tell me what your idea is.

author: gpvanarsdale

title: MyBio Hand v1.3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The bionic allows the link of biological and electronics systems for the development of technological applications, with the objective of simulate the morphological-functional characteristics of human being.
This is a prosthetic bionic hand with 11 degrees of freedom, designed for 3d printing in order to create low cost and fast producttion prototype.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%-100%

Notes:

description.header:
-Flatter surface down
-Rafts for larger parts
-Try to print small part without rafts

description.text:
In order to assemble all the printed parts, you will have to removed all the support so you can fit in the servos in the hand.
Also in the forearm parts you should sand the lip to fit those parts.

Introduction This mechatronic device has been designed based in the anthropometric and the natural movements of the fingers while grasping objects. Using CAD/CAM/CAE software, this prototype was developed and analyzed in order to validate the mechanical structure. Also the kynematics and dynamics of the hand was develop, so it can be determined the correct actuator for the device and the sequence for the movement. REQUIREMENTS
4xSG-92r servo
Loctite super glue
Arduino board(nano, uno, micro)
jumper wires
6v - 4Ah battery
Nylon rope 0.3-0.7 mm
5 mm Stainless steel shaft
FSR (Force Sensing Resistor)
EMG sensor Load SImulation Dynamic Model for 2 DOF. D-h Parameter(Denavit-Hartenberg)

Charcoal, the basic material for drawing, can be lost easily because it is tiny and 
fragile. This object is used as the charcoal container. It is designed to have three 
parts: the bottom, the body and the top of the charcoal container. The spiral 
structure on the body and the top of the container makes it much more stronger. 
The hollow structure on the bottom enables the container to pull in or out 
conveniently, thus when you are going outside, you can pull it out and put the 
container in your pencil-box, and when you come back you can return the 
container to the bottom. The container can save 5 charcoals maximum at the 
same time and the high of the container equals to that of charcoal, therefore it is 
safe to save your charcoals inside.

You could adjust the screw slits to allow other sizes of fans. My fan was 80x80x25. I wired it in directly to the main.

title: Foot for tube leg (table/ chair/etc) Parametric and Angled

description.text:
Parametric foot for the end of hollow tube. Made to insert into the tube and provided a solid foot. Angle parameter prints a foot for legs that are angled with respect to the floor (like most are). Now you can print foot that inserts into a tube of any diameter, that is any angle, and has any size foot. Enjoy, and feel free to modify for uneven floors, or table legs that aren't even. Blue skies,
Jim Rasmussen
TabSynth Design Works LLC

No

No

0.27 or standard

20% seems plenty solid

remixed_from.author: AminimalStudio
remixed_from.title: Torso of an Emperor, Roman Imperial

description.text:
This is my first iteration of a 3D printed book. I have been meaning to work on this idea for a while - and with a new perspective on the summer - i have been able to find the time to develop it. I have been thinking for some time how it would be nice to produce a book of textures and reliefs. To publish and distribute all the wonderful architectural patterning and decoration we enjoy here in Chicago and beyond. The impetus for this project was a call for submissions from the Center for Book and Paper here in Chicago at Columbia College. The exhibition calls for both "print on demand" and "photographic" books. This "publication" is my response. I think that - for now - the accordion style format is the most realistic. Although i would love to do some kind of traditionally bound book format - as a 3d printed object. I also was wary of printing the whole thing in one go - it would easily have been a 80 - 100 hour print - and a lot could go wrong in that time span. After some experimentation with other connectors I prototyped a modular hinge and a modular surface that could be joined together with tbusers pins. I chose six 3d scans scans from Thingiverse, three of my own and one each from Jason Bakutis / The Met, Pretty Small Things and AMinimal Studio. The scans - to my knowledge were (probably) all created with 123d Catch or another photogrammetry application. The "front cover" explains how these reliefs were created, and has the Creative Commons License for the work. The "back cover" is a list of works. These two elements were created in Illustrator saved out as svg files, imported into tinkercad and extruded / booleaed with a Modular Surfaces. This piece is very much a prototype. I am very happy with the Modular Hinge - and the Modular Surface - tbusers pins work wonderfully - i plan to use this combo on other art pieces soon. I am also interested about possibly stacking more of these to create columns, or making attachments to fix to a wall and make relief systems from them. The pages do not stack perfectly, i would rearrange the order perhaps as follows:
  • olmec, 2. boddhistiva, 3. mayan head, 4. lion, 5. emperor, 6. ogre
    • but as i had already made the list of works and i'm short on time this is what it is. also i think some kind of separator between the pages would have been good too. To check out more of my artworks please visit: http://tomburtonwood.com

title: Assistive Joystick - For finite hand movement

description.text:
See full information - code making instructions - on GitHub
https://github.com/paulbardini/Assistive-Joystick Please help to better this device. This joystick was created as an alternative computer mouse to help a sick family friend. After battling Guillian-Barre syndrome with a short-term period in induced coma, my friend’s rehabilitation required to re-learn basic hand movements and other physical activities which many of us take for granted. This joystick was designed to sit in the hand while lying in bed. The large button on top of the device reduces the amount of effort required to perform a mouse click, while the joystick creates a more controlled method of positioning the mouse cursor. Apart from helping out a friend, I want this project to be released to the community, within an open source ideology, in hope that this may help others in similar situation, or used in ways that are not intended here. Please – take this idea and recreated it. Modify/redesign it to be used for an alternative reason. With the help of an open community, this project could assist many people in need.

These are the files for a set of wipers for some glasses that i deigned for a school project.
Please feel free to modify them and improve on them as you find necessary.
There may be duplicate files so only print what you think is required.
To make them you will need some electrical tape (for the wipers) two small motors (like the ones you get in children's electronics sets) and a switch (you will probably need to modify the STL files to fit your switch). you will also need to drill two extra holes in the large pieces to get the wires in if you can not get them all through the two existing holes (i couldn't). i made the battery pack out of two AAA battery is stuck together with tape and taped wire on the terminals.
Thanks for looking at my thing.

ps do not use the piece with the attacher built in if your printer is not very good with supports or you are using a dissolvable support material (i would just get the attacher and glue it to the other side part.

title: Larger Ultimaker 3D Printer with wire rope instead of belts

description.text:
From my previous Ultimaker X(2X), Y(2X), Z http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73468 I have learnt many things about building my own 3D printer.
I am now starting to build my next 3D printer which I am adding all of my previous knowledge and I will be uploading progress videos onto you tube https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCFihgbMpXdIzcH1IYlHgQ3w This printer will be using 2mm wire rope to drive both the X and Y axis.
The extruder will also be mounted on the gantry reducing the length of the Bowden tube.
My intention is to have two lead screws on the platform which will also be linked with one motor using 2mm wire rope.
The main frame is made from 2mm H22 Aluminium.

comments.text: any updates????
comments.author: MG3009

comments.text: Toothed belts are normally used for synchrous timing and non slip, how will you ensure the wire cables do not slip on the stepper drive pullies for example??
comments.author: DGA

comments.text: To make them not slip, you mount a 'drum' or cylinder on the stepper that has a radial (not longitudinal) hole in it. Then you thread the wire through the hole and wrap the wire around the drum on either side. This will enable no slipping/backlash using a wire to drive pulleys.

title: brio straight rail for electric trains to go under bridges

description.text: https://youtu.be/6koWg3lI7pg I don't know excactly what happened into BRIO ingeniors minds, but somewhere in the process of building the electric trains, they just forgot about how high their brigdes are. That's to say: not so high at all. Edit: added a version with holders that prevent the rail from sliding under the bridge Now I could understand that years after years, they made their products evolve. That's a good thing. But their tracks is still the same standard. And when you buy an electric train in his box, the boxes states nowhere that this new engine wont fit under your bridges and wont make it through your tunnels. That's lame. Anyway, thanks to @strepmud, here, it was only a mater of minutes to derivate a rail that would just set it back to right. It aint perfect, but you can use all sorts of bridges again, without the need to modify them! It is still delicate though. Be sure to adjust the rail is such way that the engine is not touching the bridge. it is a tight fit. Because of that, I also split it a '3/4' sized version (you need two of them to run under the bridge), and even an extension that you can insert between them so you can go under double, triple, quadruple (ect) bridges too. Isn't that cool? :-) And if somebody want's to send me some woodfill filament...

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

as high as possible, but .2 should do fine

Notes: On the center of the rail, support of wheels just vanishes. You need a perfectly leveled bed, and print whitout raft nor supports. You need to remove the part very gently. If you use glass, let it get cold first.

comments.text: very cool! the bridge problem was annoying me as well, but I hadn't considered making the rails lower.. :-).

comments.author: tripydevin

comments.text: Hi, looks great!  Are you using bearings?  Most designs I've seen are using bearings, but I'm looking for a simpler one without them...
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text: Hi, i desgined it without the use of ball bearings. I am using the plastic surface of the printed parts as a friction bearing. Its perfect for those slow speeds and needs absolutly no service like BB would need (oil). Also this combination has less friction then any sealed BB. The inner diameter is 8mm. But through printing it will be smaller like 7.8mm. So i just put a 8.0mm drill slowly through the printed part. Afterwards it was perfect with the M8 rod.

A 1918 Mack AC Bulldog. Still a bit of a work in progress but I'm not going to get much time in the next month or so, so I'm posting this up flaws and all Its designed to print in 1:48th but the mesh is full size so you can scale as you wish The main problems still to be resolved;
  • windscreen very fragile
  • front axle mounts very fragile
  • No interior
  • The nose shape is a little flat on the sides, its not too bad but could do with a little refining if you want to print it bigger than 1:24th
  • No headlights (though many didn't have these anyway)
  • The dumper has no mechanism to tip it (yet)
    • I will be resolving these issues when I have time but with some careful work the current model prints out ok. Also included is several cab variants including with and without side doors, with and without windscreen, I have seen some real ones with no back window, I think they were the ones that went to World War 1 but will do a version of that as well.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: The windscreen and front axle are rather delicate at the moment, these will require some refining but can be printed and cleaned up without breaking if you are careful.
Designed from a drawing by Ken Musgrave I have a design drawing by Ken Musgrave marked 1986, I have not included it but its commonly available on the internet.

title: Small items sorting box with printable innserts

description.text:
This is Version 2 of a small item storage box with 3d printable removable inserts.
i have used sortimo boxes but they are costly as hell and i never seem to have the right insert box at hand when i need to store something. This version can be cut with ordinary woodworking tools or on a lazer cutter, Inserts are 3d printable. Future versions will include boxes that can be cut with a lazer cutter or woodwroking tools. I will make a few different versions, 30 mm deep, 60mm deep and 90 mm deep. The box is laser cut in my case but there should be no problem making the box with ordinary woodworking tools. This is made in Autodesk inventor i have uploaded the entire project file. I will make a "build with woodworking tool" version. The internal storage cups can be 3d printed at home or from a 3d print service, they can probably be made from wood as well. This version has 3,6 mm plywood as a base material for the box. Ill see how sturdy it turns out to be in use to see if i need to increase the thickness of the base wood material. PS: This is a early prototype. i have not yet refined this to include hinges, locks, carrying handle, etc. If you have any suggestions or wishes please let me know and i will include your suggestions if they make sense.
